text.p: These are the leading stories in the Malawi press on Friday.
Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Foreign donors and the government are in a tug-of-war over a proposed provision in the National Roads Authority Bill which gives the Ministry of Works full control to disburse funds.

- The Malawi Supreme Court on Thursday ordered the Electoral Commission to hold a one-day voter registration exercise at three centres in Nsanje Central province in southern Malawi, where a parliamentary by-election was called off in February 1996 after parties complained of irregularities.

- The Civil Servants Trade Union has dismissed as cosmetic the announcement by government to cut by 10 percent the salaries of President Bakili Muluzi's and his cabinet members, saying it is a ploy to win support.

- The position of chief executive for Malawi's biggest conglomerate, Press Corporation, may go to an expatriate whose predecessor was earning $20,000 a month, although rumours say the position has been offered to Eunice Kazembe, Chief Executive of the Agicultural Development and Marketing Corporation (ADMARC).
